channel.title: Urgent Help Needed!
channel.description:
Hello,
I am having problems with my laptop (has ALL of my school stuff and other important things on it). It won't boot windows due to a looping blue screen, and I can't reinstall it (makes me have to wipe entire thing). So I decided to go to Linux. This was fine (running off a Knoppix Live CD) until my computer electrocuted me (again) and the CD drive partially broke. Now, I've got an Ubuntu CD working and I am trying to install it, but the built in partition tools apparently only work with NTFS systems, while mine is FAT32. So, how could I make a new partition in the scenario? Is there any kind of partition software that can run on a cd without windows? Thanks for your help, Justis EDIT Btw, when the CD drive broke, Knoppix no longer loads :( Also, I need this to be as cheap as possible. Thanks

item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

Oh. Well, now that I realize all the things that are wrong with my laptop (thank goodness for warranties :P), my school will most likely give me ANOTHER new one (I screw things up fast :P). So, I’ll just partition that (after I backup my stuff off of this).
Thanks again
What college do you go to?

@moparisthebest wrote:

I use kubuntu 7.04 (amd64 on my desktop, i386 on the laptop)

If I was going to start from scratch again, I may have to go with the sabayon mini-cd (because the dvd installed is 11gb), it is pretty nice looking.

item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper

item.title: Urgent Help Needed!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I believe you can do it with kubuntu by installing some packages, but I know sabayon linux will do it automatically. http://www.sabayonlinux.org/ (you can get the mini-cd instead of the huge DVD)

Read full topic

item.title: Urgent Help Needed!
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

You can? Thank you very much, but I just have 1 last question (and if this doesn’t work, screw it I’m sending it to bestbuy who’ll send it to China), do you know of Linux Live CDs that do that? Preferably not Knoppix as apparently it doesn’t work. Or actually, anything on a cd that can do that… like I have a kind of DOS live cd (But I don’t think it can).

Read full topic

item.title: Urgent Help Needed!
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

Wow, linux is so much better… but thats kind of weird I edited at same time you posted, but anyways, is there something wrong with my hard drive? Is there any way I could recover the materials (Maybe with a Live CD that can edit the normal hard drive?

Read full topic

item.title: Urgent Help Needed!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest

@moparisthebest wrote:

item.title: Urgent Help Needed!
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

Ok, is it possible to do that off a live-cd? I never knew you could install things.
Thanks again!
I got it, I ran it as root, but after resizing, it says this is virtual or something, then it says:
Filesystem check failed! Totally 64 Cluster accounting mismatches!
Is there something majorly wrong? Because my computer does overheat sometimes and if pressure is applied to the frame it causes weird lines to go on the screen… hmm maybe I should have mentioned that before I’m sorry.

Read full topic

item.title: Urgent Help Needed!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Try to install qtparted and use it.

‘sudo apt-get install qtparted’

Read full topic

item.title: Urgent Help Needed!
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

They do? When I looked at GPartEd, I tried it and it gave me a bunch of errors. I will go back onto my laptop and post them here.
Thanks
Also, I don’t have any spare flash drives (that I can have wiped for an OS :()
I would take the hard drive out, but I don’t want to void the warranty, and if I gave it to my school they’d just give me a new one… they don’t like to fix my mistakes
Edit:
Before I continue with GPartEd, I just wanted to make sure:
When I make a new partition, do I have to rename it or anything? Or can it just be as-is? Also, should I make a 3rd under file-system Linux-swap?
Thanks for all the help
Justis
Edit again:
Here are the details.
GParted 0.2.5

Resize /dev/hda1 from 55.89 GiB to 51.30 GiB ( ERROR )

check filesystem on /dev/hda1 for errors and (if possible) fix them ( ERROR )

ntfsresize -P -i -f -v /dev/hda1

ntfsresize v1.12.1 (libntfs 8:1:0)
Using locale ‘en_US.UTF-8’.
Device name : /dev/hda1
NTFS volume version: 3.1
Cluster size : 4096 bytes
Current volume size: 60011610624 bytes (60012 MB)
Current device size: 60011610624 bytes (60012 MB)
Checking filesystem consistency …
Accounting clusters …
Cluster accounting failed at 10357753 (0x9e0bf9): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357754 (0x9e0bfa): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357755 (0x9e0bfb): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357756 (0x9e0bfc): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357757 (0x9e0bfd): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357758 (0x9e0bfe): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357759 (0x9e0bff): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357760 (0x9e0c00): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357761 (0x9e0c01): missing cluster in $Bitmap
Cluster accounting failed at 10357762 (0x9e0c02): missing cluster in $Bitmap
ERROR: Filesystem check failed! Totally 64 cluster accounting mismatches.
This software has detected that your NTFS is corrupted. Please run chkdsk /f
on Windows then reboot it TWICE! Important, don’t forget the /f parameter!
Afterwards you can run ntfsresize. No modification was made to NTFS.

========================================

Create Primary Partition #1 (ext3, 4.00 GiB) on /dev/hda

========================================

Create Primary Partition #2 (linux-swap, 256.00 MiB) on /dev/hda

========================================

Unfortunately, I really don’t understand any of that cluster-mumbo-jumbo.
Thanks so much
Justis

Read full topic

Linux partition tools (gparted or qparted) do work with fat32

I am having problems with my laptop (has ALL of my school stuff and other important things on it). It won’t boot windows due to a looping blue screen, and I can’t reinstall it (makes me have to wipe entire thing). So I decided to go to Linux. This was fine (running off a Knoppix Live CD) until my computer electrocuted me (again) and the CD drive partially broke. Now, I’ve got an Ubuntu CD working and I am trying to install it, but the built in partition tools apparently only work with NTFS systems, while mine is FAT32.
